author: Detroit Free Press
title: Big Ten football | Brady Hoke second-guesses Michigan's Harbaugh | Buckeye Xtra Sports
text:
Brady Hoke defeated Michigan State once in four tries as Michigan’s coach before he was fired in December.
But had he been in the hot seat for the Wolverines’ fourth down with 10 seconds left against the Spartans on Saturday, he said he could have sealed the victory.
Speaking on his SiriusXM radio show on Tuesday night, Hoke said he would not have punted, as Michigan coach Jim Harbaugh decided (which led to punter Blake O’Neill fumbling the ball to Jalen Watts-Jackson for a 38-yard touchdown with no time remaining, giving Michigan State a 27-23 victory).
>> Get the most out of your Ohio State experience, follow @BuckeyeXtra on Twitter 
“When you play armchair quarterback, the only thing I would say is you’ve got to play to the strength of your football team — and the strength of Michigan’s football team all year long has been their defense,” Hoke said.
Asked if the punt was the problem, he broke down the issues.
“There’s too many mechanical parts to it,” Hoke said. “The one gunner to the field should have been in a little bit more. If you are going to be in, there’s ways to protect it a little bit better.
“Hold the guys, have the other guys come in a little bit. ... You’ve got to play to your strength, and your strength is your defense. And if it’s a Hail Mary and that’s all, it would have been.”
His co-host, Mark Packer, cut him off and asked about going for it on fourth down.
>> Got a question about Ohio State football? Ask the experts! 
“Your playbook is open now,” Hoke said. “If you throw the ball, the clock is going to stop anyway, if you don’t make it, because of the fourth down. You have an ability to give (tailback) De’Veon Smith the ball, challenge your offensive line or play-action pass because Michigan State is going to be aggressive. You take some time off the clock, 4 or 5 seconds. A 60-yard field goal, (Michigan State’s Michael) Geiger before the game was 5 of 9, and it’s a 60-yard field goal.”
O’Neill bobbled the snap, another issue Hoke said would have been avoided if they ran a fourth-down play.
“A quarterback takes 1,000 to 2,000 snaps from center every single year,“ he said. “In practice, there may be 150 of them when (you) count the prepractice snaps and different things.”
Hoke said he can relate to a decision ruining a potentially huge victory.

“I know it’s easy from where we sit right now,” he said. “I’ve been on the sidelines and had to make decisions. We went for two against Ohio (State) two years ago because Devin Gardner had a broken foot, didn’t think the defense was playing as well as we needed to play, so go for the win (in a 42-41 loss). Jimmy (Harbaugh), I’m sure, they went over what they would do, how they wanted to do it, communication all over the place. Personally, if we had the No. 1 defense in the nation, I’m going to test those guys.
“You’ve got to have that confidence in your players to go make plays. With that defense, pressure on the quarterback, make him get the ball out. I’ve seen the (1994) Colorado-Michigan Hail Mary a thousand times, but your strength of your team is your defense. Guys up front, go pressure during the whole game, play to your strength, and that’s your defense.”
